Bleed

An important consideration when printing leaflets commercially is including bleed with your design/artwork. Bleed is utilized when a colour, text or graphic is to be printed right up to the trimmed edge of your leaflet. It is essentially an area outside of the normal size which can be trimmed off to give no blank paper at all. This as a result of the small movements of a few mm when trimming a large stack of paper with a guillotine, to allow the best final result.

Different printing companies work with slightly different sizes with bleed, but 3mm can be a reasonable excess to leave. For example then, an A5 leaflet which is normally 148x210mm should have a page size of 154x216mm, contributing 3mm to every side.

It is also worth leaving a space relating to the trim line and the spot where your leaflet info is, not just to make sure it doesn't get trimmed, and having text too close to the edge can look unprofessional and a little haphazard.

Resolution

As soon as sending your artwork to commercial printers, it is necessary that the resolution to your artwork is high enough to make sure that when printed it is actually sharp and clear. Business printers usually require artwork at least 300dpi (dots per inch) to create good prints, the problem occurs when images together with text are supplied with lower resolution than this and are then expected to be reproduced as they simply look ";on screen";. Your normal internet images are generally 72 or 96dpi, and look fine when viewed for a monitor, but make an effort to get these printed out and you'll see the massive difference in quality. All dedicated design packages will assist you to save at 300dpi (or higher), and that needs to be the minimum requirement as soon as saving as. jpg and also. tiff file types.

High res PDFs are just a bit different, as fonts usually are embedded, so the document does not have an overall resolution. It can depend on the settings of each one package, nevertheless images in PDFs should be exported as at least 300dpi and any commercial print settings ought to be selected, since above using CMYK and with bleed, your PDF should then get OK to print from.

Period

More important than other things is time. Due to the fact the other tips, even though ignored, can all be corrected, given plenty of time. It's not necessarily possible to leave several time, but even an extra few days to give the printer a way to flag up any problems, delivering time to correct them, are able to avoid costly mistakes and reprints. This also gives you chance to go through your proofs with a smaller amount pressure, turning it into more likely you are able to spot any glaring problems.
